conversation.message: Hello School_C Admissions, I’m Student_C. School_C is my first-choice school, and I’m very eager to enroll if offered a place. I value the opportunity to learn and contribute to the community at School_C. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_C. Since all schools share the same priority order (A > B > C > D > E), I am mid-priority everywhere and could lose my top option if I wait. With capacity 1, I should apply immediately to School_C to maximize the chance of matching with my first choice before it fills.

conversation.message: Student_C, thank you for your application and for naming School_C as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_C. We look forward to welcoming you to our community.
conversation.thought: Student_C applied to us as their first choice. Our true priority ranks Student_A and Student_B above Student_C, but neither has contacted us this round. With quota 1, accepting Student_C now secures a mutually high-preference match and avoids the risk of ending unmatched if higher-priority students never apply to us (they may be captured by School_A/School_B based on their preferences). Student_C is on our acceptable list, so accept.

conversation.message: Hello School_A Admissions, I’m Student_B. School_A is my first-choice school, and I’m very excited about the opportunity to join your community. I’m ready to commit if admitted and would be grateful for your consideration.
conversation.thought: School_A is my top true preference. All schools share the same priority order and I am ranked second after Student_A, so the best chance to secure a top outcome is to apply immediately to my first choice before capacity is taken.

conversation.message:
Dear Student_B,

Thank you for your application and for naming School_A as your first choice. We’re pleased to offer you admission to School_A. Please confirm that you would like to finalize the match with us.

[ACTION] [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1 and only Student_B applied this round. On our true priority list, Student_B is ranked 2nd (behind Student_A). However, Student_A has School_A as 2nd choice (prefers School_B first), so there is a meaningful chance Student_A will not apply to us or will match elsewhere. Rejecting Student_B now risks ending up unmatched or with a lower-priority student later. Accepting Student_B secures a high-priority match within quota and is consistent with their stated first-choice commitment.

conversation.message: Hello School_D Admissions Committee—I'm Student_D. School_D is my first-choice school, and I’m applying because I strongly want to enroll if admitted. I’m committed to contributing positively to the school community and taking full advantage of your academic and extracurricular opportunities. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: My top true choice is School_D, and all schools share the same priority order where I am ranked below A/B/C. I should apply to my first choice immediately to maximize the chance of landing it before capacity fills, and clearly signal strong commitment and fit.

conversation.message: Dear Student_D, thank you for your application and for naming School_D as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_D. We look forward to having you join our community. [ACCEPT]
conversation.thought: We have quota 1. Student_D applied and ranks 4th on our true priority list (A, B, C, D, E). In round 1, only Student_D has applied to us. However, Student_A/B/C all rank School_D low (4th/5th/4th), so they are unlikely to apply to us early; Student_D ranks us 1st, making them the most likely secure match. Holding out risks ending unmatched if higher-priority students never apply. Therefore accept Student_D now to fill quota with a committed applicant.

conversation.message: Dear School_B Admissions, I’m Student_A and School_B is my first-choice school. I’m excited about the opportunity to join your community and would be honored to enroll if admitted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: School_B is my top true choice. All schools share the same priority order with Student_A ranked first, so applying immediately to my first choice should secure an acceptance before any uncertainty arises in later rounds.

conversation.message: Dear Student_A, thank you for your application and for naming School_B as your first choice. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_B. We look forward to welcoming you to our community.
conversation.thought: Student_A is the top-ranked student on School_B’s true priority list. They have applied in round 1 and explicitly state School_B is their first choice, making acceptance immediately optimal. With quota 1, accepting now secures the best possible match and avoids the risk of losing Student_A to another school in later rounds.

conversation.message: School_E is my first-choice school. I’m applying because I strongly want to enroll and would commit immediately if accepted. Thank you for considering my application.
conversation.thought: Apply immediately to my top choice, School_E. With identical priority lists at every school (A highest to E lowest), my acceptance chances are best at a school that other higher-priority students are less likely to rank first. Student_A targets School_B first, Student_B targets School_A first, Student_C targets School_C first, and Student_D targets School_D first, so School_E is likely uncontested in round 1. Securing an early match at my #1 is optimal.

conversation.message: Student_E, thank you for your application and for naming School_E as your first choice. We appreciate your clear commitment. We are pleased to offer you admission to School_E. Congratulations—we look forward to welcoming you.
conversation.thought: As School_E with quota 1, my true priority ranks Student_E last. However, in this round only Student_E has applied to me. Given Student_E lists School_E as first choice, they are likely to commit if accepted. Waiting for higher-priority students (A-D) is risky because all of them rank School_E last and are unlikely to apply unless rejected elsewhere. To avoid ending unmatched, it is optimal to accept Student_E now.
